comment.author: 25966588@N04
comment._content: Wow! It's changed so little, and yet so much!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
@ Wardie44B - I had another look, and still think the two photos are taken at the same time (within a few minutes).  There are differences caused by the strong sunshine and contrast in this picture - a building disappeared (was it the Hotel Australia?).  This photo is a full plate glass negative; the other is half plate.  In this photo the tram wires have been purposely whited out (see persistent URL).  

The best proof comes from the two carts on the left hand kerb (see note) - the one in front has the same arrangement of parcels in both pictures - see Persistent URL.

The tram wires (post December 1899) and the absence of electric lights (pre 1904) should help date the photos.

Or maybe I missed something?!

comment.author: 47572660@N08
comment._content: Sorry, beachcomberaustralia, I thought there were buildings missing up the Macquarie Street end. Obviously an exposure problem.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: No dramas, it is always good to look at the pictures closely again.  I have scribbled on so many of these photos now that some remarks should obviously be questioned.  I am no expert on photography, history or Sydney, and I am learning it as I go along.  I welcome the opinions, knowledge, and contributions from anybody interested.

comment._content: Google Earth seems to love placing everything at St James including this one.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: This fantastic pic of Martin Place appeared in the T&CJ in February 1892...I'll hang it here just for interest - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71234386 Also just for interest, here's a 1904 Sydney Mail item on the Bank of Australasia building, which had then recently been completed - news.google.com/newspapers?id=9GxVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UpUDA... ;
